newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West spot power up amid hot weather, BPA hike.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West spot power up amid hot weather, BPA hike.

text.p: U.S. West spot electricity prices rose Thursday amid outlook hot weather in the region and Bonneville Power Administration's (BPA) hike of its next-day power prices, brokers and marketers said.
Temperatures in western U.S. are forecasted to be above normal to much-above normal in the next six to 10 days.
BPA reportedly increased the value of electricity in 18 hour blocks for Friday delivery to $23.00 per megawatt hour (MWh), up from Thursday's price of $17.90 for 16 hour deals.
Today's prices were also buoyant by growing sentiments that hydroelectric output would slow in Septmember.
Further north at the Mid-Columbia (Mid-C) delivery point in Washington, firm, peak electricity prices for next-day delivery were quoted at $20.50-$23.00 per MWh, up from $15.50-$16.50 on Wednesday.
September Mid-C electricity was pegged at $18.00-18.40, up from Wednesday's $17.25-$17.75. December Mid-C was offered in the $18.25 area.
Down at the Palo Verde (PV) switchyard close to Phoenix, Ariz., next-day electricity for peak, firm delivery was valued at $23.00-$25.00, up from Wednesday's $22.00-$22.50 range.
Next-day PV power for firm, off-peak delivery was quoted at $10.00-$12.00.
September firm, peak PV were quoted at $20.30-$21.00, down from $20.70-$21.25 on Wednesday.
Some market sources attributed the weakness in September PV to the ongoing decline in September natural gas prices.
October PV electricity, with similar delivery terms, was assessed at $16.65-$17.10, up from Wednesday's range of $15.75-$16.50.
Fourth-quarter 1996 PV were quoted at $14.75-$15.30, down from Wednesday's $16.20-$16.50 range.

Arizona Public Service Co said today it shut a 745 MW coal-fired power unit at the Four Corners generating station near Farmington, N.M., to repair a boiler tube leak. The unit is expected to return to service in a few days, the company said.
